articles.headline: How a Crypto Compliance Officer Ended Up in a Nigerian Prison
articles.snippet: Tigran Gambaryan, an American compliance official for the giant cryptocurrency exchange Binance, flew to Nigeria in February for a planned two-day business trip. He hasn’t returned.
articles.abstract: Tigran Gambaryan, an American compliance official for the giant cryptocurrency exchange Binance, flew to Nigeria in February for a planned two-day business trip. He hasn’t returned.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he flew to Nigeria for a business trip in late February, Tigran Gambaryan, a top compliance officer at the cryptocurrency exchange Binance, packed a small suitcase with just enough clothes for two days.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: Colleges Warn Student Demonstrators: Enough
articles.snippet: After years of tolerating unruly protests, some schools are starting to suspend and expel students, raising questions about where they should draw the line.
articles.abstract: After years of tolerating unruly protests, some schools are starting to suspend and expel students, raising questions about where they should draw the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 100-year-old annual honors convocation at the University of Michigan is typically a decorous affair, with a pipe organ accompanying golf-clap applause.

articles.headline: Apple Says It Was Ordered to Pull WhatsApp From China App Store
articles.snippet: Apple said it removed WhatsApp and Threads from its China app offerings Friday on Beijing’s orders, amid technological tensions between the U.S. and China.
articles.abstract: Apple said it removed WhatsApp and Threads from its China app offerings Friday on Beijing’s orders, amid technological tensions between the U.S. and China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple said it pulled the Meta-owned apps WhatsApp and Threads from its app store in China on Friday on government orders, potentially escalating the war over technology between the United States and China.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Modi’s Power Keeps Growing, and India Looks Sure to Give Him More
articles.snippet: Few doubt the popular prime minister will win a third term in voting that starts Friday. His strong hand is just what many Indians seem to want.
articles.abstract: Few doubt the popular prime minister will win a third term in voting that starts Friday. His strong hand is just what many Indians seem to want.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he campaigns across India for an election that began on Friday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi speaks of his insatiable ambitions in terms of dinner-table appetite.

articles.headline: With a Fresh Look and Recipes, Manischewitz Courts a New Generation
articles.snippet: The 136-year-old company’s products have been staples in American Jewish households for generations. After a major rebranding, the matzo ball soup comes with merch.
articles.abstract: The 136-year-old company’s products have been staples in American Jewish households for generations. After a major rebranding, the matzo ball soup comes with merch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something wasn’t quite right about the chicken soup.

articles.headline: Israel’s Strike Was Smaller Than Expected, and So Was Iran’s Reaction
articles.snippet: The relatively limited scope of the attack, as well as a muted response from Iranian officials, may have lowered the chances of an immediate escalation, analysts said.
articles.abstract: The relatively limited scope of the attack, as well as a muted response from Iranian officials, may have lowered the chances of an immediate escalation, analysts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The relatively limited scope of Israel’s overnight strikes on Iran, and a subdued response from Iranian officials, may have lowered the chances of an immediate escalation in fighting between the two countries, analysts said on Friday.

articles.headline: ‘It’s Clearly Bleak’: Stocks Notch Longest Losing Streak in Months
articles.snippet: A rally at the start of the year has given way to worries on Wall Street about economics and geopolitics.
articles.abstract: A rally at the start of the year has given way to worries on Wall Street about economics and geopolitics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks suffered their longest losing streak of the year, as geopolitical turmoil rattled Wall Street and investors slashed their bets on the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates any time soon.

articles.headline: Ukraine Aid Bill Clears Critical Hurdle in the House as Democrats Supply the Votes
articles.snippet: Democrats stepped in to support bringing the aid package to the floor, in a remarkable breach of custom on a key vote that paved the way for its passage.
articles.abstract: Democrats stepped in to support bringing the aid package to the floor, in a remarkable breach of custom on a key vote that paved the way for its passage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The House took a critical step on Friday toward approving a long-stalled package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and other American allies, as Democrats supplied the crucial votes to push the legislation past Republican opposition so that it could be considered on the floor.

articles.headline: Chinese Export Surge Clouds U.S. Hopes of a Domestic Solar Boom
articles.snippet: The decision by a Massachusetts solar company to abandon plans to build a $1.4 billion U.S. factory highlights the risks amid a flood of Chinese clean energy exports.
articles.abstract: The decision by a Massachusetts solar company to abandon plans to build a $1.4 billion U.S. factory highlights the risks amid a flood of Chinese clean energy exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, CubicPV, which manufactures components for solar panels, announced that it had secured more than $100 million in financing to build a $1.4 billion factory in the United States. The company planned to produce silicon wafers, a critical part of the technology that allows solar panels to turn sunlight into electrical energy.
